titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: V.15— Wednesday

Breakfasted with Charles at the Globe Hotel, with Mr and Mrs Sidney Brooks. At 11 Mr Peet called with Dr Milner and Mr Derbyshire an Englishman, and we went about five miles out of the City to the Institution for the deaf and dumb—8 classes, about 150 pupils—a teacher to each class— Exhibition of their proficiency— Returned between Noon and 1— Call with Charles at Davis and Brooks’s Store— Saw C. A. Davis. S. Brooks went with us to the new Exchange now building of Quincy Granite— Charles went to dine at Mr Wilkes’s— I at the Astor House— Packed my trunk— Letter to L. C. A. Invitation from Mrs Clinton for to-morrow evening— Answered the Note— Left
my Cloak and Umbrella and two unsealed Letters in the Parlour—dined. Seated by Mr Bridge, a Son of my deceased Classmate— Dr Francis Parkman— Hurried away to Steamboat Narragansett— Left my two unsealed Letters in the Parlour— Charles joined me at the boat— Left the Battery wharf at 5. P.M— Thick fog soon came up— Whist with General Sumner and two others, unknown—
2. V. Thursday Stonington— Boston— Quincy.

Thick fog all Night— Sounding every half hour Lightning— Thunder— Heavy rain— passage protracted from 2 to 6. A.M. when we arrived at Stonington Rail-road— Providence 45 miles at 1/2 past 8. Cross the ferry— Railway Cars to Boston. arrived at 11. A.M— Left Charles— Shaver and Hair-Cutter. Call on Governor Edward Everett— Report of Conversation with Mr Gallatin— Northeastern boundary— At Charles’s house— His wife and children well— Dined there—with Mr P. C. Brooks— After dinner Charles brought me out to Quincy— He returned to Boston— L. C. Smith here— John Kirk and his wife— Home [symbols] Letter to my wife
3. V. Friday.

Rainy morning— E. Price Greenleaf called and returned Wieland and Klopstock— Wrote and copied a long Letter to Joseph Blunt. Visited my garden— Many trees lost— Vine transplanted— Seed from H. L. Ellsworth— Writing slow— Diary running into arrears. Evening visit at Mrs T. B. Adams’s—Mrs Stebbins—Elizabeth C and Isaac H. Met French the Schoolmaster— Town Hall lights up— Asked him what it was— Said it was a farce— Letter from George A. Otis with his translation of the Tusculans— Had met him yesterday, walking from the Railway depot— Sundry other Letters received— Diary arrears.— Met Daniel Parkman yesterday in Boston, with something under his arm. He explained [symbols]
4. IV:30. Saturday.

Clear Cold Gale— Whole day occupied in writing out my remarks at the table last Tuesday— Visit from President Josiah Quincy— Mrs Quincy, much out of health. Mrs Josiah Quincy junr. came— Edmund Quincy much indisposed— Exhibition at Cambridge next Tuesday.— Edmund Quincy to pass the Summer at the Mansion here— George A. Otis walked out from Boston—dined with us— Walked to Mrs Russell’s to return thence in a Chaise to Boston— Conversations on Cicero. Flattery too fulsome— Enthusiasm for Cicero— Free thinking weak-minded— E. Price Greenleaf— Offer to copy Papers— Mr P. C. Brooks came out with Charles— Has bought D. Webster’s House for 32000 dollars— Webster going to England— Mr Brooks and Charles returned to Boston. Letter from L. C. A. [symbols]
5. IV:45. Sunday.

Heavy gale from the Southwest— Heard Mr P. Whitney this morning from Job 42:5. and afternoon from Luke 10.38–42. Read Saurin—3d. Sermon of the 2d. Vol. of the New Sermons—preceded by a prayer, and preached on Whitsunday.— I answered Mr John H. Eastburn’s Letter this morning, and wrote a short one to my wife this Evening— Employed the leisure of the day in revising partly the Discourse for publication— Evening visit from Mr Beale, and his daughter Caroline.
6. IV:15. Monday.

Morning visit from Mr Whitney— Isaac Hull Adams here— Letters to S. A. Turner, and Charles Larrabee— After dinner Charles came out from Boston, with his wife, and little Charles but returned— Elizabeth C. Adams was also here with her brother— I visited my garden, and trimmed a few trees—particularly the largest of the maples in the
seminary from the seeds which I brought from Philadelphia, and planted 1. June 1835. This tree is now about 12 feet high, and the trunkinches round. Its growth has been more rapid than any other of which I ever sowed the seed— The growth of several others of the same seeds has also been vigorous— I trimmed also several Horse Chesnuts growing finely, and several Shagbark walnuts— First appearance of a peach tree at the North east corner of the Seminary. I found a number of Appleseeds up, when I arrived, but they promise little. I revised my Discourse for publication, and took for motto upon the title page, a passage from the first Tusculan, C. 14. Charles brought me out a Letter from G. A. Otis, with the loan of W. H. Prescotts History of Ferdinand and Isabella— I received also a Commission as Justice of the Peace throughout the Commonwealth for seven years from 10. April 1839.
7. IV:45. Tuesday

Exhibition at Cambridge— I went into Boston in Gillett’s Omnibus—passed from that into the Cambridge Hourly—and found President Quincy, and Governor Everett, with a few others of the visitors already in meeting— The reports from all the Professors and from the President were read by the Governor— Paley’s Moral Philosophy. I told President Quincy I wished they would burn it, by the hands of the common hangman— Bowditch’s Navigator a perfect Treatise of practical Astronomy. Quaere de hoc— The Exhibition very good— Two Kings— Thomas Worthington, Son of Edward, and Archibald Gracie son of James G. King, spoke a Latin dialogue between Caius Marius and Granius— Mr James M. King was there, and came and spoke to me— The best performance was a Dissertation upon the effect of Belief in Immortality upon Literature by Nathaniel Holmes Morrison of Peterborough New-Hampshire. James Lawrence a son of Abbot Lawrence had a part of a Greek Dialogue in Iambic verse between Juba and Syphax. The Governor had Chancellor Harper of South-Carolina with him, and did not stay to dine— The dinner was pleasant— S. T. Armstrong and Mr Carter of the State Senate—and R. C. Winthrop Speaker of the House, were there— Dr Francis Parkman sat next to me, as I had left him at the Astor-House at New-York.

After dinner I went with President Quincy to the chamber of Mr Lawrence’s Son— Found Mrs Lawrence and her daughter there, but he was gone— Returned to President Quincy’s where I saw his 4 daughters and Mr Waterston who is to marry the youngest Anne, and Miss Waterston his Sister— Mr Quincy took me in his Chaise to Boston, to Charles’s house, but he was just gone— We followed him down to Hawley Place, and found him there— He brought me out to Quincy, and returned himself to Boston— Evening idle— Deacon Sullivan with his Son, and I. H. Adams were in Gillett’s omnibus this morning.
8. IV. Wednesday

Sharp frost— My thermometer at 30. at Sunrise— Mr Smith a book pedlar brought me a subscription paper for a book called the World as it is—which I declined— I said I did not like to subscribe for a book without knowing what it was—whereupon he pulled a thick small octave volume out of his pocket and I saw upon the title page it was the 4th. Edition and still declined to take it— I visited my Orchard where I found Kirk had set outof my seedling fruit trees which had been growing in boxes, all of which he has broken up and thrown away. I am thus totally disappointed in my project of ascertaining, whether the trees will bear the same variety of fruit with that of the seed— And I must now abandon that experiment, with regard to apple and Pear trees, of which I can never see the result, and concerning which I leave no one who takes any interest in it— Charles came out this afternoon—blew up a rock in front of his house and returned to Boston— Mrs Angier was here from Medford, with a family from Cape Haytian, a brother and three Sisters named Cavallo who have been residing some years with Mr Angier— They had dined at Mrs T. B. Adams’s, and were returning to Medford— They are about to depart on their return home— I made up my despatch containing my Jubilee Discourse, addressed it to Joseph Blunt at New-York and sent it to the Post-Office— Wrote a short page of Letter 2. to the Petitioners—
9. IV:30. Thursday

Sun rose 4:45— I wrote this day only 3 pages of my Letter to the Petitioners and the day was gone.— I. H. Adams was here in the morning. E. P. Greenleaf and my Son, in the afternoon, and Mr Daniel Greenleaf and Revd. W. P. Lunt in the Evening. I find it impossible to write half so much every day here as I can at Washington, when Congress are not in Session— I visited my garden and seedling trees with Mr. E. P. Greenleaf— The day was warm; but the frost of the Night before last and that of the preceding Night have scorched many opening leaves of the trees— The Peaches cherries and plums are in full blossom— The Pears and Apples just opening— Nothing but Appleseed, and one early Ann Peach yet up. I finished the reading of G. A. Otis’s translation of the first Tusculan—on the contempt of death.
10. IV:15. Friday. Sun rose 4:44.

Dr William Graves of Lowell called this morning on a visit of curiosity, being on his return home from a visit to a patient at Scituate— Read part of Otis’s translation of the second Tusculan, upon bearing pain— Compare it with Olivet’s Seminary— Two more peach seedlings break ground— Wrote 4 small pages of the 2d Letter to the Petitioners: E. Price Greenleaf Divided the two stems of the Black Jack-Oak in the Nursery, and set out one of them at the North eastern end of the garden, with a root upwards of a yard long— Trimmed the large garden maple— The frost has scorched the ends of the leaves just opening on the chesnut trees— Visitors in the margin— Cold and clear day and evening— Read a few pages of Prescott’s Ferdinand and Isabella— Brilliant Northern light Still dissatisfied with my day’s work— Letters from N. Curtis, and Petty Vaughan— Release for 20.000 dollars.
11. IV. Saturday. Sun rose at 4:43. Fahrenheit 30.

Went to Boston in Gillett’s omnibus— Mrs Stebbins Stetson of Commercial Point— At Charles’s Office then at his house. His daughter Louisa Catherine was run over day before yesterday by the wheel of a Carriole, and by almost a miracle was only much bruised—no bones broken— Charles’s Office again. 9.? Calls at the Merchant’s Insurance Office to see Mr Nathl. Curtis— He came at last to Charles’s Office— I advised him to take Mr John Lowell’s opinion upon the Indenture of release, sent by Mr Petty Vaughan for us Executors of Ward N. Boylston, to execute, and to compare it with the proposition made by P. Vaughan before and which we accepted— I spoke to him also of the life Estate in the farm at Weston left me by W. N. Boylston, and requested him to mention my wish to Mrs Boylston, to purchase the remainder which is hers, or to dispose of my life Estate to her—or to join with her in a conveyance of the whole to a third person— Met B. W. Crowninshield—Joseph Hall and P. P. F. Degrand; and Dr. Francis Parkman— Call at Dr. George Parkman’s. He was out— He afterwards came to Charles’s Office, where I met him— Exhibition of Alston’s pictures— Saw Mrs B. Gorham there— I dont like his Jeremiah— My ticket N. 1893— Exhibition room quite full. At Harding’s— Slippers and gloves— All too small— Met Reuel Williams. Dined with the Trustees of the Agricultural Society at Mr Thomas L. Winthrop’s. Adams, P. C. Brooks, Henry Codman, Henry Colman, H. A. S. Dearborn, Saml. Elliot (Mayor of the City) Edward Everett (Governor) Mr Finney, Saml P. Gardner, J. C. Gray— B. Guild. Jos: Quincy jr. David Sears, Robt. G. Shaw, Dr John C. Warren, John Wells—Reuel Williams and Mr Winthrop with his Sons R. C and Grenville T. and Mr Derby were the company— At Charles’s House, Elizabeth C. Adams— Evening at Mr Abbott Lawrence’s—Mrs Lawrence Revd. Andrew Bigelow now Minister at Taunton— Returned to Charles’s house— I had some expectation of the arrival of my wife and family but was disappointed— H. Colman promised to send me 2 Rohan Potatoes.
12. V. Sunday. From Boston to Quincy.

Immediately after Breakfast I went with Charles to the landing of the Providence and Stonington Railroad, and waited the arrival of the Cars, but my wife and family were not in them— Went with Mrs Charles and Elizabeth C. Adams to the federal street Meeting-house to hear Dr. Channing— He and his Colleague MrGannett were in the pulpit but the services were performed by Mr Furness of Philadelphia, who preached from 1. John 4.1. [“]Beloved, believe not every spirit, but try the spirits, whether they are of God.” The main argument of the discourse was an exhortation to try the Spirits of others, to make us acquainted with our own— Harriet Welsh there— Immediately after the morning Service, Charles took me home to Quincy, and his boy John Quincy with us— After dinner we heard Mr Lunt, from Luke 6.31. “And as ye would that men should do to you, do ye also to them likewise”—a discourse exhibiting the true character of Christianity.— Mr Lunt took the occasion explicitly to declare his disapprobation of Slavery, though in very mild and moderate and in the discharge of what he believed his duty as a minister of religion— Shortly after the Service Charles returned with his Son to Boston— I read the 4th. Sermon of the 12th. volume of Saurin; upon the covenant of God with the Israelites— His text is 29. Deuteronomy, from the 10th. to the 19th. verse—preached on the afternoon of a communion day; and the drift of his argument is that the covenant of Christians with God by the communion, is the same as the covenant of the Israelites with God, as recorded in that chapter of Deuteronomy— I had occasion to use this incident in my late Discourse to the New-York Historical Society; and might perhaps have taken some hint form this Sermon if I had read it before— I visited with Mr E. Price Greenleaf, the seedling trees, in my Nursery Garden and Seminary— The succession of four or five frosty mornings, has been a sore trial to the blossoms of the fruit trees—which are full upon the peach, cherry, plum, pear and apple trees— I found it impossible this Evening to read.
13. IV:30. Monday

Mr Bartlett, Cashier of the Quincy Stone Bank came yesterday to see my son; but he was gone— His object was to say that Mr Holbrook of Randolph would take my shares in the Bank at par— I told him I expected Charles would be here again on Tuesday— This morning Mr Jonathan Arnold now of Pembroke came to enquire if his father is not entitled to a pension— His grandfather was taken in July 1777 in the Hancock frigate, Captain Manly and carried into Halifax where he died of the small pox— His father was born just before the death of his grandfather, and while he was absent— The claim of my visitors father, has been stated by Mr Jacob H. Loud to Mr Edwards the Commissioner of Pensions who has answered that Thomas Arnold the father is not entitled to a Pension for the Revolutionary Service of Nathaniel Arnold the Grandfather— My visitor had a copy of the Act of 1. March 1837—and thought that would apply to claims for revolutionary service, but it manifestly does not; as it expressly refers to what the deceased would have been entitled to in 1835.— He said however that his Grandfather besides his service in the Hancock frigate, had also served two years before on land; but he could not tell whether the whole of both services amounted to six Months— I promised to examine the pension Laws, and write to Albert White Esqr of Hanover whether if six Months service by Nathaniel Arnold could be proved his Son Thomas Arnold would now be entitled to a Pension. My day was occupied in writing upon my second Letter to the Petitioners—and reading G. A. Otis’s translation of the second Tusculan, on bearing pain— Visited my Nursery Gardens and Seminary— Little vegetation— Received sundry Rohan Potatoes from H. Colman. Evening visit to Mr Beale— Mrs Wayles and his two daughters there.
14. IV:15. Tuesday

Showery morning, and day, which confined me to the house— 2d. Letter to the Petitioners—labours— G. A. Otis’s third Tusculan upon grief— The French Translation by President Bouhier excellent. The Dialogue of the Tusculans is neither natural nor artificial. The subjects are introduced, all in the same manner, and the auditor is a mere assentator. But my troubles this day were with the 9th. Ode of the 4th. Book of Horace to Lollius— I wanted very much the other day at New-York, at the dinner table Pope’s version of the vixere fortes ante Agamemnona, but I could not remember it— I am enquiring now why Pope took only two of the passages of that Ode for imitation— I tried it myself, and was all day hacking at these lines.

lg.l: Think not because I drew my birth
From rugged rocks, and barren earth
My verse is doom’d to die—
The deathless musings of the mind
To torrid climes are not confin’d.
Or . . . Greece’s cloudless sky—
Of Antient Poet’s tis confess’d
The Bard of Smyrna sings the best
Yet not alone he sings—
The Teian Minstrel tunes his lyre
The Lesbian lass’es lip is fire—
The Theban spreads his wings
List! Romans list—to Maro’s strain—
To Naso’s every varying vein
To Horace too by turns
Hark! on your ears, Tibullus steals
Lucretius Nature’s Law reveals
And Juvenal’s caustic burns.

div.p: and here I stick on the borders of nonsense— But how many hours of this day I wasted in rumination to proceed with this Ode— I believe Pope gave it up in despair—for he has left out the final passages of the whole composition—and his last four lines are tautological repeating the same thing twice over. Francis’s translation of this Ode is beautiful; but the translation by Duncombe senior and the imitation by the younger are both very indifferent— The Ode is said to be in three parts, between which there seems to be no natural connection. The Lollius to whom it was addressed is also to have been very unworthy of the praise which it lavishes upon him.
15. IV:15. Wednesday

Morning visit from a young man named Pierce of Brooklyne, Long Island, son of Dr Pierce of Brookline in this State. The Son, is partner of a Mr Lewis, and they are agents for claimants of pensions. I had received here the answer of Mr J. L. Edwards Commissioners upon one of the claims forwarded by them—and two Letters from them containing documents in support of other claims which I promised to forward to the Commissioners— My Son came out from Boston, but returned home to dine— He brought out with him his son John Quincy, and left him here— I labour painfully with my Letter to the Petitioners, and hammered out of Horaces Ode 9 Book 4. as follows

lg.l: The crispy curls of Priam’s boy
Seduced the Spartan bane of Troy.
And many a Maid beside
And myriads, on the roll of fame
Might beam as bright as Hector’s name,
Who for their Country died.
Long before Agamemnon’s days
Heroes deserv’d the meed of praise,
And sparkling Glory’s crown—
But perish’d in the Abyss of time—
No bard had they with lay sublime
To herald their renown
The pebble on the beach out shines
The Diamond sleeping in the mines
And hidden from the day—
The Virtue that remains conceal’d
And Dulness in broad light reveal’d
Alike forgotten lay.

div.p: There are many ideas in this Ode, that I find it utterly impossible to manage; and yet I cannot shake off the desire to turn out an imitation of it— The vegetation of my Nursery Garden and Seminary has taken a start from the rain of yesterday, but of my last autumnal plantations, nothing but apple-seedlings appear and among these none of any promise— Several of my seedling budded Apple-trees, and one Cherry, put forth this Spring their first blossoms. Many of the Peaches are in full bloom; but I cannot yet ascertain how much of the fruit has been nipp’d in the bud by the frost. I wrote to Joseph Blunt—
16. IV. Thursday Sun rose 4:38.

lg.l: Not thus thy worth, my noble friend,
In dark oblivion shall descend
To After days unknown
For still while years and ages roll
This verse shall make from pole to pole
All future time thy own.
Empires and Kingdoms rise and fall
Thou Lollius shalt survive them all
Consign’d to deathless fame.
And regions undiscover’d yet
In tongues unspoken now repeat.
Thy ever honoured name
Behold the Roman, they shall say,
Who never bow’d to Passions sway
Or vice’s base controul
But still in age, as erst in Youth
For Hounor, Temperance and Truth
Preserv’d his constant Soul
Not he the consul of one year
With transient power, the good to cheer.
The man of lofty mind
Shall through all ages be obey’d
By God’s eternal dictate made
A ruler of mankind

div.p: Morning call from Mr Curtis, with an opinion of Mr John Lowell favourable to the execution by the Executors of Ward N. Boylston, of the deed of release forwarded by Mr Petty Vaughan. Also a Letter from Mr Lowell, and a release from Mrs Boylston, of any claim on her part to the farm at Weston— Mr Curtis left the papers with me, for me to make an account and statement to the probate Court in Boston as Administrator de bonis non with the will annexed of Thomas Boylston—relating to the sum recovered from the French Government and from Petty Vaughan. My Son was here for about an hour after dinner. I visited my Orchard. There are at the Western end, between the Nursery and the Northern Wall of the Orchard 159. seedling apple trees set out by Kirk from the wooden boxes at the West end of the Garden which he has broken up— My 2d Letter to the Petitioners still labours, and the Ode to Lollius suffers me not to sleep— Here are four Stanza’s more, a paraphrase of some of the ideas in the original; but which do not tally with the imitation attempted in my first three Stanzas— If I can get through the whole Ode, without giving it up like Pope in despair, it must still be all remoulded again— Charles brought me a Letter from A Hamilton with a pamphlet on banking; and Dr Channing’s Letter to Jonathan Phillip
17. IV:15. Friday

lg.l: What Fortune chuses to bestow;
Her changeful gifts of bliss or woe
He bears with soul serene
Spurns the base bribe with deep disdain
And keeps from all dishonest stain
His hands forever clean
Not hoards of wealth in his esteem
Can yield to man the good supreme
Or happiness import
Tis Virtue gives his life her charm
Tis Fortitude that nerves his arm
Tis Justice rules his heart.
These Virtues, Lollius all are thine
Possess’d of these, Golconda’s mine
No envied gem can lend—
And blest with these, no flinching nerve
Will life itself refuse to serve
His country, or his friend.
Far happier he than wealth can make
Who learns the gifts of God to take
With praise, returning breath
Content his frugal table spreads
Or pinch’d with penury still dreads
Dishonour worse than death

div.p: A Canadian refugee by the name of Fortin who fled from a charge of Treason, came in deep distress for relief, which it was in my power, but very scantily to bestow— Charles was here after dinner, and left his son Charles, but returned this Evening to Boston— Visit from my neighbour Mr Appleton who bleaches wax, and has been a wanderer about the world; and finally married his cousin Mary-Ann Greenleaf for his second wife— He has lived 2 miles from Liverpool in England at Baltimore, at Wheeling, at Roxbury, and I know not how many other places— Visited my orchard, Nursery and Garden— My Apple-bud inserted 1831. and which came out in 1832. is in beautiful blossom. 12. Shagbark trees of different ages in the Nursery and 4 in the Garden— A peach seedling up in the new seedling table of my Grandson J. Q. Adams 3d.— Mr Otis’s 4th. Tusculan which I finished reading this morning, Dr. Channing’s Letter to Jonathan Phillips Alexander Hamilton’s Letter on banking and Horace’s Ode to Lollius distract my attention and the Letter to the Petitioners languishes. I answered Mr Edgar S. Van-Winkle’s Letter for the Committee of Whig young men of New-York—
18. IV. Saturday—

My wife and family arrived from Washington, which they left last Wednesday Morning— Miss Cutts came with them— And Charles and his wife and daughter came out from Boston to their Summer residence— I had little sleep again last Night— But working between 2 and 3. O’Clock finished my imitation of the Ode to Lollius, excepting the last Stanza, which had escaped my recollection in bed but which contains too beautiful an idea to be omitted— What a magnificent panegyric upon his friend! What consciousness of his own transcendent powers! what a sublime conception of the gifts of poetical inspiration! But then what a sad falling off that all this praise was bestowed upon a worthless man!— A misfortune to me is that I cannot enjoy the music of this ode— The harmony of all the metrical Stanzas of Horace is lost to my ears excepting the Sapphic. It is remarkable that Horace who avows himself a very swine from the sty of Epicurus, whenever he inculcates virtue resorts to the Stoic fountain— His Lollius is a perfect Zeno— If Pope who barely glanced at this Ode had imitated the whole of it, nothing that he ever wrote would have been more exquisite— In watching my seedlings, I took up a young elm of the third years growth, leaning too much on the seminary fence next the gate; and set it out in the Northern border of the Orchard— I likewise cut off a shoot from the old stump of an elm in the orchard, with one root adhering to it, and set it out on the Northern border, with a view to ascertain whether it will live in its separate state, and whether the old stump will survive—an experiment repeated from that of the black jack Oak I sowed some old Ash seeds, shagbark walnuts and Apple seeds and Pear Cores in the summerhouse cellar where I expect none of them will come up— I received from Mr Gerrit Smith his pamphlet Letter to Henry Clay, and from Mr Nathaniel Ingersoll Bowditch a memoir of his fathers Life prefixed to the translation of the 4th. volume of the translation of La Place’s Mecanique Celeste— Also a Letter from Amasa Soule and Samuel Crowell, Committee of the Bath Mechanic Association, for a 4th of July Address.
19. IV:15 Sunday.

Heard Mr Lunt this morning, from Matthew 3.11. [“]I indeed baptize you with water, unto repentance: but he that cometh after me is mightier than I, whose shoes I am not worthy to bear: he shall baptize you, with the holy Ghost, and with fire”— Upon the peculiar force of the testimony of John the baptist to the truth of Christianity— The few transient notices of John the Baptist in the Gospels, with the allusions to him in the prophets of the old testament, especially in the 4th. Chapter of Malachi which terminates so abruptly, form a subject for an impressive Dissertation— Mr Whitney preached this afternoon, from 1. Corinthians 15.19. “If in this Life only we have hope in Christ, we are of all men, most miserable.”— Mr Whitney’s voice, and eyes, and teeth are all failing; and it is painful to hear him titubate in his reading— In the decay of his physical powers, I see an exemplification of my own— Mr Degrand dined with us— Went after meeting to the Point, to examine the Estate of Mr Josselyn, came back to tea—and late in the Evening returned to Boston— I read the 5th. Sermon of the 12th. Volume of Saurin; upon the Fast day of the 5th. of April 1724— He threatens them with the judgments of God for their Sins, but censures Jonas for failing to execute the command of God to announce the destruction of Niniveh in forty days, for fear that the prophesy would not be accomplished— Saurin does not share his hearers— We had Evening visits from Doctor and Mrs Woodward—and from Mr Beale and his two daughters— Charles and his wife were also here— I read about half of Mr Otis’s translation of the 5th. Tusculan, upon the sufficiency of Virtue, for happiness, but the day was so cut up, that my progress in the second Letter to the Petitioners was small— I began reading in the Bible with the children again— At Solomon’s Song—
20. IV:30. Monday—

The Weather changeable and rain much wanted— There was a small sprinkling, not enough to moisten the ground this afternoon— The plume blossoms of the Horse chesnut are rising upon the tree before my window— The lilacs coming into full bloom— The tulips opening their cups— The ash-seedling cotyledons appearing above ground and peach tops daily pricking their passage through the surface of the Earth— I took up ten seedling cherry trees self-planted under the mazzard at the Northern Wall of the orchard and set them out again— I finished reading Mr Otis’s translation of the 5th. Tusculan, upon the sufficiency of Virtue for happiness— This translation is so literal that it follows the latin idiom and turn of phrase so as to read very stiff in the English; but it has been executed with laborious care, and is in general very correct.— My second Letter to the Petitioners still absorbs nearly the whole of my time, but I am now drawing to the conclusion of it— Mr and Mrs Angier from Medford called here upon their return from a visit to her mother.— I paid a visit to Mr Daniel Greenleaf whom I found alone— His wife died shortly after our departure last Winter for Washington— They were cousins, and had lived together 62 years, without having ever been separated more than ten days at one time from each other. Mr Greenleaf is now 77 years of age, and is a living Chronicle of the olden time at Boston— He gave me information of sundry persons, and families whom I had formerly known, but of whom for several years I have lost sight.— Charles spent the Evening here but his wife did not come. The Children are learning French, and read this Evening a lesson from Telemachus.
21. IV:34. Tuesday. With the Sun—

I finished my second Letter to the Petitioners which I intended to make very powerful, but upon reading it over I find so feeble, and at the same time so unsparing that I hesitate whether to send it— I have promised however and cannot consistently withhold my reasons for being opposed to the immediate abolition of Slavery in the District of Columbia, and in the Territory of Florida— There is a great want of method in the composition of this paper, which will not give satisfaction to any party—and there is in it perhaps too little respect for persons.— The obligation of meeting adversaries face to face, and the admonitions of Prudence are greatly at variance with each other— This Letter weighs much upon my Sprits—but it must go— I visited my Garden, Nursery, Seminary, and Orchard— My cherry seedlings yesterday transplanted have an unpromising appearance— I went to the large Elm just beyond the turn of the corner towards Mr Thomas Greenleaf’s, and picked up what I could find of Elm-seeds which were not more than a dozen, which I sowed with dry last years ash seeds in the Garden Summerhouse cellar— I found a second seedling wild plum, but neither of them promises to live— I was called from my searches in the orchard to Alpheus Spear who settled with me for two Quarters of his Rent to the 31st. of March— I received from Oliver Carlton, corresponding Secretary of the Salem Lyceum, a Letter inviting me to deliver the introductory Lecture to their next Winter’s course on the last week of October, or the first of November next— I know not what to do with these multiplied and repeated applications. I spent the Evening at Mr Lunt’s with Charles. His wife was here— I have received from Mr P. S. Du Ponceau, of Philadelphia, a Volume called the Silk culturist’s manual, by John D’Homergue—and from Mr J. P. Bigelow, Secretary of this Commonwealth the first Session pamphlet of the Acts and Resolves of the State Legislature—
22. IV:30. Wednesday—

A Northeasterly storm with rain all the morning, which compelled me to resort to a fire in my chamber. I revised my second Letter to the Petitioners; and enclosed it to Gales and Seaton, for publication in the National Intelligencer, if they see fit— Having done this I wasted the day, in deliberating, what I should take up next— I read a Sermon of the Revd Simeon Doggett—Pastor of the 2d Congregational Church at Raynham preached there on the last Fast day of 28 March 1839. a copy of which I this day received from Revd. Andrew Bigelow of Taunton— Then Dr Channing’s Letter to Jonathan Phillips—intended as a refutation of Mr Henry Clay’s Anti-Abolition Speech in the Senate last February. Then Rees’s Encyclopaedia. Article Astronomy—Schubert’s Popular Astronomy.— The first book of Ovid’s Metamorphoses, and Count de Maistre’s translation of Plutarch’s Essay upon the delay of divine Justice, which he promised to dedicate to me, but forgot his promise— This Dissertation interested me so much, that the Sun went down and I had done nothing.— I can compare myself to nothing but the humming bird, which visits my Althaea trees in August when they are full blown— Buzzing upon the wing, from cup to cup without alighting any where, and sipping liquid honey with a long needle beak from the bottom of each cup— My paraphrase of the Ode to Lollius remains unfinished and I have an invincible repugnance to commencing, precisely upon that which I ought above all others to take in hand— A Letter from Mr Frye calls upon me for heavy repairs to the Columbia Mills— And estimate of 615 dollars—with hints that it must be increased to 800 and a plain intimation that a complete repair of them will cost at least 3000 dollars— A grievous burden which I cannot shake from my shoulders. Charles and his wife, and Isaac Hull Adams were here this Evening— The weather allowed but a partial visitation to my seedling trees, but I gave Kirk the Chinese and Baden corn received from Mr H L Ellsworth and Pumpkin seed from A. Lawrence.
23. III:45. Thursday

I rose before four O’Clock, and the weather being unsettled though with out rain, I spent no small part of the day in visiting my garden Nursery, Seminary and Orchard— My seedling trees of which I have now several hundreds, forest and fruit, from ten years of age to the first plumelet just shooting from the ground of the present Season, afford me a sort of Shandean pleasure, with many disappointments and mortifications, as I see many a promising seedling perish one after another— For raising of trees from seeds; with profit and improvement, half a century of uninterrupted practice observation and study are required— I laid out nursery plats, for each of my six grand-children last Summer, to shew them the process of vegetation of trees and if possible to give them a taste for planting which they may pursue with the blessing of Heaven through a long life— They have now peach, pear, and apple-seedlings out upon all of them— There are nuts and acorns in the ground, but which do not yet appear.— I called this morning at the Quincy Stone Bank and made a Deposit— Mr Bartlett the Cashier was not there, but is confined to his bed with a fever— His Son, a boy of 14 or 15 attends in his place— At the Quincy Patriot Office— Mr Green promised to republish my 1st. Letter to the Petitioners; but said it was so long he must divide it into two papers— He promised also to publish the second; even if Gales and Seaton should decline to publish it— At Mr Gill the bookbinders shop I ordered the Quincy Patriot for the first and second years 1837. and 1838 to be bound in one Volume— Green promised to send the missing papers, which are from the 10th. of November 1838 to the end of the year.— I wrote to Mr Frye at Washington, and authorized the repairs upon the Mills, according to the estimate which he sent me, and which I returned. I wrote also to Oliver Carlton, corresponding Secretary of the Salem Lyceum; and to Amasa Soule, and Samuel Crowell, Committee of the Bath Mechanic Association, Maine, declining to deliver the introductory Lecture to the Lyceum next November, and a 4th. of July Address to the Bath Association— Our Ladies took tea at Charles’s, and I spent the Evening with them there.
24. IV. Friday

Foul weather. A cold Northeast storm confined me to the house almost the whole day. I ought to have done much— Mais helas! il nen est rien. There is such seduction in a library of good books that I cannot resist the temptation to luxuriate, in reading, and because I have so much to write that I count all time lost, that is not spent in writing— I finished reading Dr Channing’s Letter to Jonathan Phillips upon Slavery— He demolishes all the argument of Clay’s Speech, which is indeed nothing at all— The remark of Junius that the arguments of tyranny are as despicable as its power is dreadful applies especially to all arguments in behalf of Slavery. I answered the Letter of Dr Sprague of Albany, which I received at the Astor House, and by inadvertance put into my trunk. I have promised him the manuscript of my Semi-centennial Discourse— I wrote also to the Commissioner of Pensions James L. Edwards, and enclosed to him the Declarations of Sarah Lennington, and of Maria Varick of New-York, to obtain widow’s Pensions—papers which I received from Messrs. Lewis and Pierce of Brooklyn Long Island, after I arrived here from Washington. I looked into Goguet’s Origin of Laws, Arts and Sciences for the earliest History of Astronomy; and also into the first Volume of the Cours d’Etudes Encyclopediques by Francois Page’s—but neither of them was so satisfactory as the German popular Astronomy of Schubert— I fear I must renounce this enquiry or it will immediately lead me beyond my depth; and I might as well attempt to swim across the Atlantic— Another enticement is my old friend Count Maistre’s translation of Plutarch’s Treatise on the delays of divine Justice, the notes to which are so characteristic that they bring him before my mind’s eye as if I had seen him but yesterday— And thus the hours glided in liquid lapse away, and the day was gone— Charles was here and spent the Evening with us.
25. V. Saturday

Rainy morning— Thunder and lightening—after which it cleared up and I visited my seedlings— Charles went to Boston and returned home to dinner— I read Alexander Hamilton’s pamphlet and answered his Letter— Mrs Mary Jane Lawrence was here and I returned to her the Land warrant issued to her husband for military service in the last War with Great Britain; in which she has a right of dower, and her son James Monroe Lawrence a right of inheritance to the remainder— I informed her of the offer of Mr James Winney on the 16th. of Feby last at Washington, of 5 dollars for the whole of both rights to the land, being 160 Acres of land in Missouri— She spoke of petitioning Congress for another pension, because she invested the pension for five years which she has received, in the American Bank, which has broken, and she has lost it all— She says there are in Cohassett several widows quite wealthy who receive pensions—and she being poor, cannot see why she does not receive one— I told her that if she wished to petition Congress again, at the next Session, and I should be there, I would readily present her petition— She said Mr Parmenter had told her, that she ought to receive a Pension, and he thought Congress would grant it. I advised her then to get Mr Parmenter to present her petition, as he was in higher favour with Congress than I— Count de Maistre’s translation of Plutarch on the delays of divine Justice took another hour, and I attempted to commence an Essay upon Astronomy, but the Sun was going down— Walk over the Hills— Charles’s Stone wall just finished. Red wedge Apple tree in blossom— Saw the Sunset from Charles’s porch at 7:23— Isaac Hull and Elizabeth C. Adams, Charles and his wife spent the Evening here— Among my occupations now I undertake to write one page a day for a collection of my Nugae Albas, or fugitive pieces in verse, chiefly written for the Albums of Young Ladies—and autographs, the fashion of which is somewhat annoying.— Nugae Albae—White lies—
26. IV. Sunday Sun rose 4:29. Set 7:25

Mr Morison of New-Bedford preached this morning from Acts 17.23 “For as I passed by and beheld your devotions, I found an altar with this inscription—To the unknown God” This is a very common text, but the application of it, by Mr Morison, was peculiar to himself; for he said that this altar inscribed to the unknown God was the human heart—in other words that religion was a natural want of man universally felt— That the revelations of the Holy Scriptures were bestowed to supply that want, and that the natural man, without that supply was always groping for it in the dark— Mr Morison is a graduate of Harvard University of 1831, and looks consumptive, as do almost all the young clergymen in this part of the Country— He dined with us and preached after dinner from Luke 15.24. “And they began to be merry”— His application of this text was as unusual as that of the morning. It is taken from the parable of the prodigal Son; but the substance of the Discourse was an argument to refute a prejudice very common especially among young persons that religion is dull and gloomy— I read the 6th Sermon of the 12th Volume of Saurin—a thanksgiving Communion, remarkable for some very democratic observations upon kings and royalty—which at this day it would be dangerous for any minister to make in monarchical Governments, and he adds that what he says of kings is equally true of Republics— I wrote half a page of the introduction to an Essay upon Astronomy, of which I fear that I shall make nothing. Copied also some of my own verses— Saw the Sun just risen, and saw him set from Charles’s house— He and his wife spent the Evening here— Evening visit also from Mr E. Price Greenleaf.—
27. IV. Monday.

Showery— Measured the tallest of the Maple Seedling trees, from the seed which I brought from Philadelphia, and planted 1. June 1835. It measures 7 inches in circumference just above the ground, and is about 12 feet hïgh— The grass was thickening and encroaching round my standard circles in the seminary— I had them all clipped, and most of them weeded— I had also large limbs sawed off, from an old Peach tree, and an old Apple tree, to see if I can renovate them in the Forsyth plan . . . transplanted Oak, two elms and cherry seedlings are not yet dead, but shew feeble signs of life.— I despatched a Letter to S. H. Walley at Boston, with enclosed introductory Letters to Lewis Cass, Minister at Paris, and T. Aspinwall, Consul at London— And I answered a Letter from J. Marston at Taunton— After dinner I went over the Hill with Deacon Spear and George Vezey, who calls upon me for a survey and agreement for repairing the stone wall fence between his land and mine— Charles went with us— Sprinkling of rain— After returning I looked up my Diary, the index to which has been running in arrear from 1. Octr. 1st 1834. a period of excruciating affliction in my life.— I found it, and began the attempt to redeem my recording 11. days— The day was thus consumed— A travelling Book pedlar named George Titcomb, brought me 10 numbers of a semi-monthly periodical called the common School Journal, for which he asked my Patronage— I subscribed for one copy and paid a dollar for the year’s subscription— Charles spent the Evening here, and it set in for a steady rain— At the close of the Evening I copied some of my own verses— I found my Diary for October 1834. a record of solitary morning walks of 4 and 5 miles—and of Plantations of nuts, acorns and seeds— I then took great pains to mark the seeds to ascertain whether the fruit would follow the variety of the seeds— It is so of nuts and acorns—
28. IV:15 Tuesday

Showery Morning.— Charles went to Boston, and brought back Isaac Hull Adams— Mrs John and Mrs Charles F. Adams with Miss Mary Estelle Cutts went also to Boston and returned to dine— Dr Robbins of Mattapoisett called here on his way to Boston where he is going to attend the Annual Meeting of the Antiquarian Society— He told me that Leonard Hammond with whom I went to the Secretary of the Treasury Woodbury, the day before I left Washington, had returned to Rochester, and was grateful for the kindness that I had shewn him— Mrs Charles brought out from Boston a blue box that I had left at her house last November and which I had forgotten— I found in it the Note from Dr. James Laurie of 1. June 1836—for which I have made such long and fruitless searches— I wrote on it an order of payment to N. Frye, with a Letter to Dr. Laurie, demanding payment; which I enclosed in one to Mr Frye— He cannot receive it till the 1st. of June— I wrote also an answer to a Letter received from Mr W. B. Calhoun of Springfield— I declined the invitation to deliver an address there on the next 4th. of July— On looking over my fugitive pieces in verse; it was like a dose of nauseous medicine; to find them so numerous; and all in one Style of level mediocrity— It is a waste of time to make a collection of them— And yet I must make it— Then I took up my manuscript first pages of my father’s life—laid aside since August 1833. nearly six years; and what have I been doing in all that time? Planting seeds and nuts and stones to come to nothing—and drudging like a Slave in a constant minority at Washington to counteract mischief—utterly unable to accomplish any important public good— Charles was here this Evening without his wife— I found one shagbark seedling walnut shoot 20 inches long.
29. IV:30. Wednesday.

Dr George Parkman and Mr George A. Otis were here this morning— Dr Parkman’s visit was short, as he had to attend the annual meeting of the medical Society. Mr Otis remained to see Mrs Adams, and read to me Letters from W. H. Prescott, H. G. Otis, W. P. Greenwood, G. Parkman, President Quincy, and one or two others commendatory of his translation of the Tusculan Questions— Mr Otis wishes for a similar Letter from me, for publication, and that it should be all praise. He has devoted many years to the translation of all Cicero’s philosophical writings, and his attached to his task has become a sort of fanaticism— He thinks himself entirely on a par with Cicero— After dinner I went to the Quincy Stone Bank and transferred 20 shares of its stock toThe Certificates of the Stock I have mislaid— I left at the Bookbinder Caleb Gill’s shop the 6 numbers of Mr Felt’s Annals of Salem to be bound— At the printing Office of the Quincy Patriot I gave Mr Green a copy of the document 297. The correspondence of the defaulting receivers and Collectors with the Secretary of the Treasury— He promised to send me tomorrow the proof of the first part of my first Letter to the Petitioners— Mr E. Price Greenleaf came and looked over with me, my garden and Nursery seedling trees.— The English white Oak, at the bottom of the Nursery, which he thought dead, is putting out its leaves and shoots from the ground upwards to its topmost branch— Mr Greenleaf advises against heading down trees that grow up with slender stems which he says in England are called pollards— I do not altogether agree with him in this opinion. The French Rohan potatoes sent me by Mr Colman; are already breaking ground in their hills— The Ladies spent the Evening at Mrs T. B. Adams’s and Charles and I, after a visit to Mr P. Whitney joined them— Mrs Angier is there.
30. IV:15. Thursday
Boston— Historical Society— Quincy.

I went into Boston this morning in the Carriage— At Charles’s Office, I found Franklin’s Translation of Cicero’s Treatise upon Old Age which had been left there by Dr. George Parkman—and shortly after met Dr. Parkman himself— I went with him to Faneuil Hall, and saw my Portrait painted by Page, which is placed in the centre of the East end of the Hall, immediately under the Bust of my father— Dr. Parkman went with me to the Booksellers James B. Dow 362 Washington Street where I purchased a copy of G. A. Otis’s translation of the Tusculans. Dr Parkman here left me— I went to Mrs S. A. Otis’s and gave to Harriet Welsh a Letter I had received this morning for her from Mrs De Wint— I gathered in the Mall a handful of Elm-seeds with which the ground was covered— Attended the Meeting of the Historical Society. Mr T. L. Winthrop presided. Dr. Robbins of Mattapoisett, read a vote adopted by the Antiquarian Society yesterday appointing a Committee, to devise means for procuring a History of the United States— After some debate a Committee of 3 was appointed of the Historical Society to confer with the other Committee on the subject— President Quincy, Dr Robbins and myself were now chosen. I read the Letter of Mr J. Fenimore Cooper and Daniel Hall, and enquired if any person could give the information desired; but no one could tell. I. P. Davis took Mr Cooper’s Letter, and said the Admiralty Court Records were all lost— A Committee reported that they had sold for 1500 dollars to the Boston Library Company— The room belonging to the Society in Franklin-place— They were authorised to execute the deed— I nominated Daniel D. Barnard of Rochester New-York as an honorary member of the Society— Came home to dine. Charles and his wife and family dined with us— I sowed in two Pots and elsewhere in the Garden, sundry elm seeds gathered in the Boston Mall this Morning— In the Evening I walked with Charles and visited Edmund Quincy, who comes as an Invalid to recover his health
31. IV:15. Friday. Sun rose 4:26.

Visited all my seedlings; my passion for which is Shandean— The Peach-trees have been coming up the whole month. The Apples and Pears had shewn themselves in April— Very few of them yet show their second pair of leaves— None have yet been scorched by the Sun— Ash seeds came up early in the month—

Harvey Field was here, and paid his half year’s rent to 1. April—for which I signed a receipt— President Quincy called, being here to visit his Son Edmund— He spoke to me of Mr G. A. Otis’s desire to receive a degree of Doctor of Laws at Harvard University— Mr Otis has dedicated the Translation of the Tusculans to him— And Mr Quincy thinks this raises an objection to his proposing Mr Otis for a Doctorate, to the Corporation— Mr Quincy mentioned also the earnest desire with which Dr Robbins of Mattapoisett had solicited the degree of D.D. and said it had been conferred upon him at last at the special request of Governor Everett— Louisa C. Smith went to Boston with Charles, and returned to dine— Mrs Edward Miller and her daughter visited the Ladies— I gave Charles a check on the Quincy Stone Bank for 500 dollars, to complete the discharge of my debt to Isaac Hull Adams, consequent upon my father’s bequest to him which was done— Hull and his Cousin John Foster, with Charles and his wife spent the Evening here— A slip from the Quincy Patriot of next Saturday was brought me, which I revised of the first part of my first Letter to the Petitioners.— Charles brought me from Boston a Letter from Mr N. Curtis, with a Quit-claim from John Lane Boylston, and Ward Nicholas Boylston of the Weston farm. Also a Letter from Petty Vaughan, announcing the death of Nicholas Boylston, the son of Ward Nicholas Boylston, by his first wife Ann Molineux—he died at London on the 23 of April. Kirke and Thomas bottled a Cask of Vidonia wine 148 bottles; and cleared out the cellar in which last Summer a shelf broke down and smashed at least 100 bottles.
